title: Duke Criteria for Infective Endocarditis
description: Provides standardized diagnostic criteria for infective endocarditis based on clinical, microbiological, and echocardiographic findings. Classifies patients as having definite, possible, or rejected endocarditis.

parameters.name: blood_culture_major
parameters.description: Blood culture positive for IE - typical microorganisms from 2 separate cultures OR persistently positive cultures OR single positive culture for Coxiella burnetii

parameters.name: endocardial_involvement
parameters.description: Evidence of endocardial involvement - positive echocardiogram (vegetation, abscess, prosthetic valve dehiscence) OR new valvular regurgitation

parameters.name: predisposition
parameters.description: Predisposing heart condition or injection drug use

parameters.name: vascular_phenomena
parameters.description: Vascular phenomena - major arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions

parameters.name: immunologic_phenomena
parameters.description: Immunologic phenomena - glomerulonephritis, Osler nodes, Roth spots, rheumatoid factor

parameters.name: microbiological_evidence
parameters.description: Microbiological evidence - positive blood culture that does not meet major criterion or serological evidence of active infection with organism consistent with IE

result.name: diagnosis
result.description: Duke Criteria diagnostic classification for infective endocarditis

ranges.interpretation: Infective endocarditis is rejected. Consider alternative diagnoses. Criteria not met for possible or definite IE, or firm alternate diagnosis established, or resolution with ≤4 days antibiotic therapy.

Possible infective endocarditis. Findings are consistent with IE but do not meet criteria for definite IE. Consider further diagnostic workup including repeat echocardiography, additional blood cultures, and specialist consultation.
Definite infective endocarditis. Immediate antimicrobial therapy indicated. Cardiology and infectious disease consultation recommended. Consider surgical evaluation if complicated IE.

references: Durack DT, Lukes AS, Bright DK. New criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis: utilization of specific echocardiographic findings. Duke Endocarditis Service. Am J Med. 1994;96(3):200-9. doi: 10.1016/0002-9343(94)90143-0.

Li JS, Sexton DJ, Mick N, Nettles R, Fowler VG Jr, Ryan T, et al. Proposed modifications to the Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. Clin Infect Dis. 2000;30(4):633-8. doi: 10.1086/313753.

Habib G, Lancellotti P, Antunes MJ, Bongiorni MG, Casalta JP, Del Zotti F, et al. 2015 ESC Guidelines for the management of infective endocarditis: The Task Force for the Management of Infective Endocarditis of the European Society of Cardiology (ESC). Eur Heart J. 2015;36(44):3075-3128. doi: 10.1093/eurheartj/ehv319.
formula: Major criteria: (1) Blood culture positive for IE with typical organisms, persistently positive cultures, or Coxiella burnetii; (2) Evidence of endocardial involvement by echocardiography or new valvular regurgitation. Minor criteria: (1) Predisposition; (2) Fever >38°C; (3) Vascular phenomena; (4) Immunologic phenomena; (5) Microbiological evidence not meeting major criteria. Definite IE: 2 major OR 1 major + 3 minor OR 5 minor criteria. Possible IE: 1 major + 1 minor OR 3 minor criteria.
notes: Developed in 1994 and modified in 2000 to provide standardized diagnostic criteria for infective endocarditis.
Major criteria carry more diagnostic weight than minor criteria in the classification system.
Blood cultures should be obtained before antibiotic therapy when possible for optimal diagnostic yield.
Echocardiography (transthoracic or transesophageal) is essential for detecting endocardial involvement.
TEE (transesophageal echocardiography) is more sensitive than TTE for detecting vegetations and complications.
Positive blood cultures with skin contaminants (e.g., coagulase-negative staphylococci) require careful interpretation.
The criteria have been updated in 2023 (Duke-ISCVID criteria) to include new diagnostic modalities.
Prosthetic valve endocarditis may require modified interpretation of echocardiographic findings.
Culture-negative endocarditis remains challenging and may require molecular diagnostic methods.
Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial for patient outcomes and prevention of complications.
Multidisciplinary team approach with cardiology, infectious disease, and sometimes cardiac surgery is recommended.
Consider alternative diagnoses if criteria are not met, including non-infectious causes of valve disease.
